div.p: Grammar [NOTE THAT THE GRAMMATICAL PARTICLES HAVE NOT BEEN FOCUSSED SO FAR IN THE SYSTEM AND NO SYSTEMATIC ANALYSIS HAS BEEN APPLIED SO FAR.]

也 is judgmental and judgmentally descriptive, never narrative: "it is the case that; the point is that"矣 narrative or narratively descriptive and marks to a currently new, currently relevant or currently conditioned narrative statement.已 is judgmental as well as emphatic or definitive: "definitively!, definitely"而已 is decisive and exclusive of alternatives: "and that is all".耳 is a less emphatic 而已.爾 is a scribal variant for 耳 and writes the same word.哉 is emphatic and marks emotionally charged statements: "!".夫 =否乎 is tentative and marks statements the truth of which is held to open to doubt: "n'est-ce pas?"

sense.def: postverbal modal particle of doubtful semantic force, often marking the generalising and non-narratively punctual and episodic modality of the verb
is to be classified as an N; is a case of N
"it may be said that, it is a fact that": marks a judgemental non-narrative verbal sentence, often as being basic
"the thing to do is": marks the generality of an imperative as being not limited to a certain occasion or time
"the thing to do now is": sentence final particle in imperative or injunctive sentences
XX如也。"the appearance this has is": final particle marking non-narrative judgemental descriptive statements
"and so the thing is that": marker of a concluding judgment or a concluding contrastive judgmental clause.
sentence final indicating perfective (like 矣, usually co-ocurring with 已)
sentence final particle after lively descriptive non-narrative sentences
"from the time specified in S onwards": subordinate adverbial verb phrase marker
marker of sentential complements, which are typically nominalised by 之/其
"this is an instance of" marks the classification of a sentence as belonging to a certain type
marker of negated abstract nominal predicate
"the general point is": particle marking a generalising judgment
particle marking the predicative function of an abstract N referring to a feature (rather than an action, or a concept etc.)
由也升堂矣，未入其室也。 "Our friend Zǐlù has ascended the main hall,emphatic modal particle marking emphasised second judgmental non-narrative sentence.
final particle marking the non-narrative sequence of sentences of one period
"be a/the case(s) in point;marks a nominal predication as definition or specification by example(s)
e.g. 吾聞之也 marker of a main sentence a cataphoric pronoun in which is specified in the sentence that follows
"the explanation is"馬不進也 the fact is; the point is that
marker of a nominalised sentence that functions as the subject of a preceding verb phrase
be identical with N, be the Ns
modal particle: a how about N? (probably corresponding to Modern Mandarin 呢)
OBI: one of the most controversial modal particles in OBI
formative of rhetorical questions
modal particle marking rhetorical questions
marker of a rhetorical question
speaking of N in principle, V can be said of it (where V is generally or typically untensed and a non-narrative generic characterisation, often of all members of a group)
topic marker with a nominalised sentence as a topic
Speaking in general of N, S
as a matter of principle
Why! But surely! Surely!
interrogative particle: "or not"
emphatic marker of the imperative modality.
"Now,", "In fact," introducing new subject for the discourse, and introducing non-narrative theoretical discourse.
particle introducing rhetorical questions 夫何
In fact... (opening a whole chapter)
n'est-ce pas?
isn't that so?, n'est-ce pas!
intensitive imperative marker, "!!"
definitely!
marker of constative theoretical modality
sentence final particle of doubtful exact function, said to be equivalent to 之焉
sentence final particle indicating a tentative modality: perhaps?
German: "etwa"> marker of rhetorical questions inviting or suggesting/presupposing a negative answer, derived from the meaning "as the only person"
marker of (probably mild) imperative sentences
MOVE TO "THEN" sentence-final particle after apodosis of conditional
modal particle inside sentence
甚矣吾衰也！emphatic sentence-internal post-verbal modal particle
particle placed after an emphatic focussed adverbial (which one might even suspect of being a transposed main verb)
postverbal particle marking an emphatic characterisation
modal particle marking new or currently particularly relevant statement (like 了)
mildly exclamatory/emphatic: definitely
perfective semi-suffix
"by now; at this stage": currently relevant verbal statement; new situation, tensed
marks a nominal predicate as definitely applying
marks a nominal predicate as definitely applying
semantically weak marker of a new beginning within a given non-narrative abstract discourse, often a tentative summarising remark
Apparently 蓋聞 marks a tentative report on what one has heard but does not necessarily believe
-it would appear-
marker of rhetorical questions
rhetorical question particle: surely not!
assertive combination of final particles
or is that not so?, n'est-ce pas
emphatic post-sentential cluster {note that the 也 goes with the sentences that precedes, and the 已矣 is close to 而已矣 which has the sentence that precedes as its scope}
marker of rhetorical questions
communicative modal particle (see XIE ZHIBIN 謝質彬 2011: 173ff)
communicative modal particle (see XIE ZHIBIN 謝質彬 2011: 173ff)
forms strong rhetorical questions, expected answer: NO!
modal particle marking a verb as descriptive of a constellation and non-narrative
particle marking the end of a comparison, resumptively: "like that, in that way"
=而已
pre-classical sentence-initial particle with unclear meaning (SHI 毛 傳："無念，念也。", possibly a trace of the volitional prefix *m-)
archaic particle, apparently close to adverbial connectors, 'and so, thus' (SHI)
stressed emphatic final particle
marks an emphatic nominal predicate, that whole predication being modified as a whole by the communicative rhetorical question particle 夫 "n'est-ce pas"
marks an emphatic and communicative statement
marks the question form of a sentence modified by 耳
marking a tentative rhetorical question
emphatic and exclamatory final particle combination
exclamatory particles

bibl.title: Studies in the Language of Zǔtáng jí 祖堂集

note.p: Sentence final ye3 frequently occurs in combination with semi-grammticalized lia3o 了. There have been numerous suggestions how lia3o ye3 了也 should be interpreted in this construction. I think that the sequence of those two markers should be interpreted along the line with their individual functions.

The typical function of lia3o 了 in ZTJ is to mark relative anteriority of a VP(X) to a VP(Y) in the pattern VP(X) + lia3o 了 + VP(Y). Lia3o indicates that an action is completed and ye3 expresses perfective, and indicating that the consequences of the action are still relevant at the moment of the speech act:
In the following example co-occurring with yi3 已:
ni3 yi3 shi4 sho4u jie4 lia3o ye3
還聽律也無？”do you still obey to the disciplinary rules?"

In the sentence above the person has already received the set of precepts, i.e. the event of being ordained is completed and has occurred in the past. However, this event has consequences which are still relevant at the moment of the speech act, indicated by the question whether the person still obeys to the precepts.
“何不問老僧？”"Why do you not ask me?"
In the next example co-occurring together with za3o 早 'already' which can function synonymous to yi3 已 in vernacular texts:
“一句子如何言說?”"How about expounding one sentence with words?"
“非言說。”"There are no words to expound (express) [it]."

sense.def: vernacular sentence final construction indicating the perfective: (already) have Ved
emphatic sentence final particle: and that's how it is, and there is nothing to add to this matter, and that's all to it
particle marking the end of quotation
double particle marking emphatically the end of a complex discourse
and that is all there is to be said (We take this difficult case to be one of a grammaticalised VP which is no longer accessible to negation, even "in principle"
definitely, without any doubt
marker of a tentative judgment sentence
